ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

DIPLOMATIC RELATIONS WITH
INDEPENDENT ASIAN COUNTRIES


    1. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour if he will take steps to establish diplomatic relations with all inde pendent Asian countries irrespective of their political ideologies provided that he is satisfied that these countries will not interfere in the internal affairs of Singapore.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore's policy - it has been repeatedly said -is to be friends with all countries regardless of their political ideologies or their system of government so long as they respect our sovereignty and territorial integrity and refrain from interfering in our internal affairs. Singapore is therefore prepared to establish diplomatic relations with all countries who want to be friends in Asia and elsewhere too. However, the establishment of Singapore diplomatic missions abroad is a different matter. This will be governed by financial considerations, personnel re sources and the degree of our interest in the various countries. So friendly contacts with countries in Asia will be maintained and consolidated, in some cases, by the establishment of our diplomatic missions and, in other cases, by official visits and by working together with them in the United Nations and other organisations.

    However, in speaking about the establishment of diplomatic ties, one feature which is somewhat unusual in the world today is the existence of divided countries. In the case of divided countries, diplomatic relations with one part of a divided country to the exclusion of the other can only mean lending support to one against the other. For this reason, we have since independence maintained, in the case of divided countries, that we would be most happy to have trade and consular

Column: 8

relations with either of them on an equal basis and that we would do nothing that would give an advantage to one side over the other.

    Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister for Foreign Affairs inform the House how many independent Asian countries have already established diplomatic relations with Singapore?

    Mr Rajaratnam: I cannot recollect the precise number. It is neither too big nor too small. But if the Member is interested, he can ask the Ministry of Culture which has a consular list of the countries which have diplomatic relations here.

ASEAN
(Benefits to Singapore and future plans)


    2. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (a) what economic or other benefits has ASEAN brought to Singapore since its formation; and (b) whether he will inform the House briefly about the future plans of ASEAN.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, ASEAN has as yet brought no direct economic benefits to its members. However, this should occasion no special disappointment because ASEAN was formed only a little over a year ago. However, during this year, it has been able to clarify for itself the possible approaches to greater economic cooperation among member states. At the ministerial meeting held in Jakarta last August, reports by ASEAN ad hoc committees on food production and supply, including fisheries, shipping, transport and telecommunications, civil aviation and tourism were approved and adopted. The Ministers further decided that these recommendations should be examined in greater detail by the ASEAN National Secretariat to decide which could be implemented immediately and which would require further study.

Column: 9



    Singapore has already given effect to some of the recommendations made at the last ministerial meeting, though all these related to tourism. Firstly, we have introduced seven-day visa free facilities to persons arriving in Singapore provided they possess valid passports, firm bookings and entry facilities to their destinations and continue their journey within seven days of arrival in Singapore. Secondly, we have agreed to accept collective passports and travel documents issued to parties of between five and 25 persons, all of whom should be nationals of a country and travelling on package or chartered tours to countries within the ASEAN region.

    Singapore, together with Indonesia, has also been pursuing the possibility of joint development of Bali as an international tourist resort. Last April, a ten- man technical fact-finding mission from Singapore visited Indonesia to make recommendations on the project to the two Governments. The mission's report has been presented and accepted in principle by the Government of Indonesia pending a more detailed assessment to be undertaken by the Stamford Research Institute.

    As to the future plans of ASEAN, the hon. Member's guess will be as good as mine. Like many other efforts at regional co-operation, ASEAN too is running into a spot of bother at the moment. I do not want to minimise these difficulties, but all I can say is that the present difficulties would appear trivial and irrelevant to what ASEAN countries would face were they to abandon altogether their belief in the need for regional co-operation. As far as Singapore is concerned, its attitude towards ASEAN has never been one of starry-eyed optimism. Progress towards regional co-operation will be, particularly in the early stages, slow, painful and interrupted by setbacks. But we are equally convinced that hard economic and political facts will push ASEAN countries in the direction of regional co-operation. However much we the members may drag our feet, each passing year will make clearer to ASEAN countries that the

Column: 10

choice for them ultimately is one of hanging together or hanging separately.

    So, Mr Speaker, Sir, to put it succinctly, at the moment as of today, I will describe ASEAN as a state of mind rather than a fulfilment.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Can the Minister state whether the present deadlock between the Philippines and Malaysia over the Sabah claim will lead to the dissolution of ASEAN, or, at best, adversely affect the future of ASEAN?

    Mr Rajaratnam: I think the hon. Member should read the newspapers because I cannot read them for him!

SINGAPORE CITIZENSHIP
(Particulars of applications from trained teachers and Divs. I and II civil servants)


    3. Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (a) how many applications for Singapore Citizenship were received during the period 1st January, 1967, to 30th June, 1968, from (i) trained teachers in the four language streams; and (ii) Divisions I and II civil servants, other than teachers; (b) how many of the applicants have been interviewed; and (c) how many of the applications (1) were approved; (ii) were rejected; and (iii) are still under consideration.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Minister to reply.

    The number of applications for Singapore citizenship received during the period 1st January, 1967, to 30th June, 1968, from trained teachers in the four language streams was 106. Of this number, 53 were from the English language stream, 24 from the Chinese language stream, 26 from the Malay language stream and three from the Indian language stream.

Column: 11



    The number of applications received from Divisions I and II civil servants, other than teachers, during the same period was 55. The number on the racial basis comprises 39 Chinese, two Malays, nine Indians, four Ceylonese and one British.

    The total number of applicants interviewed during the period was 161. Thirty-eight applications were approved up to the end of November 1968. Of this number, 10 were teachers and 28 were Divisions I and II civil servants. One application from a Division I civil servant who did not qualify residentially was rejected. One hundred and twenty-two applications are still under consideration.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): How long will it take to make decisions on the applications which are still under consideration?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I think this particular question refers to teachers. I can say that the applications from teachers will be decided very shortly.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi(In Malay): How long is "very shortly"?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I think within a month or so.

HOTEL AND CATERING TRAINING CENTRE
(Training of personnel and employment opportunities)


    5. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (a) whether the Hotel and Catering Training Centre will be expanded to train more personnel in view of expansion in the hotel trade; and (b) the number of employment opportunities which will become available from the hotels under construction and from those now awaiting planning approval.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hotel and Catering Training Centre at 305 Tanglin Road will be extended to train more personnel in view of the expansion in the hotel trade.

    Since the introduction of the training scheme for the hotel and catering industry in May last year, nearly 600 persons have completed training as receptionists, cashiers, waitresses, waiters, barmen, room stewards and stewardesses. Plans are afoot to expand the training centre to provide for a wider scope of training as well as increasing the intake of trainees to meet the expected increase in the demand for hotel and catering personnel. In this connection, we have sought assistance from the Colombo Plan and the International Labour Organisation for expert staff, equipment and fellowships for local people. It is proposed to build a teaching hotel for this purpose.

    At present, there are about 1,800 hotel rooms in Singapore suitable for tourists and the industry employs about 2,700 workers. There are 15 hotel pro jects with a combined room capacity of

Column: 13

slightly more than 4,500 rooms under way. The number of workers required to man the hotels is estimated on the basis of one and a half workers per room. With the completion of these 15 hotels, there will be employment opportunities for nearly 7,000 persons in the industry. It is estimated that by 1970 this industry will employ a total of 9,500 workers.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: Will the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour state whether there will be facilities for training the top and middle hotel management staff and, if not, whether arrangements will be made to send these trainees abroad?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: At present, there are no facilities available. But when the new hotel school is built, there may be a possibility of training the middle- rung hotel management staff, but not the top-ranking ones. At the moment, there are a few who are on training courses abroad for management staff.

STRIKES AND WORK STOPPAGES
FROM 1-1-68 TO 31-10-68


    6. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour the number of (i) strikes, and (ii) work stoppages, during the period 1st January to 31st October, 1968.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, during the period 1st January to 31st October, 1968, there were only four strikes involving a total of 172 employees and a loss of 5,299 man-days. There were no other work stoppages during this period.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Can the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour state what was the reason for the fewer strikes during this period?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I think the hon. Member should know. Anyway, I think

Column: 14

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: Can the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour state how many strikes have taken place after the enforcement of the Employment Act?

    Mr Speaker: Can you give that information now, Mr Sia?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I do not think I am able off-hand to give the number. But if the hon. Member will put it down as a question, it will be answered.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to find out from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour whether it is because of the arbitrary power that the Government has given to the employer to dismiss workers, or whether it is really due to the Employment Act that the relationship between the employer and the employee has improved.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I think the conciliatory machinery in the Ministry of Labour does its work well and, therefore, there is no need for any strike to take place.

    Mr Ho See Beng: If that is the case, does the Parliamentary Secretary presume that this good relationship will continue in the future? If it does, is there any possibility of abolishing the two Industrial Arbitration Courts so that a lot of money will be saved for the Government?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, human nature is such that there will be cases where the Ministry of Labour cannot -

    Mr Ho See Beng: Carry on.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: No, I would not use those words. I think there will be cases where the Ministry of Labour cannot get both sides to agree. And dealing with such cases is surely the purpose of the Industrial Arbitration Courts.

From January to October 1968 the Employment Exchange had placed 3,880 registrants in employment.

    It is not the practice of the Employment Exchange to take back registration cards from registrants.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson)(In Tamil): Take, for example, a person who has been employed. Does not the Parliamentary Secretary agree that if you do not take away his registration card, he will go from one place of work to another to seek employment?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, that will not be possible because once we have sent a registrant out to a prospective employer, his card in the Employment Exchange is automatically endorsed. His name is therefore taken out of the register.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy(In Tamil): My question is whether the card can be taken back or not.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I do not understand. I do not know what card can be taken back.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: I wish to know whether the registration card will be taken back, that is, the employment card. Once a person is employed, should not his registration card be taken back? Otherwise can he not continue to seek a better job at another place? That is the question I am asking and I hope the Parliamentary Secretary will answer it.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I said earlier, it is not possible for that registrant to move from job to job. Once he is sent out by the Employment Exchange, he brings with him a card addressed to the prospective employer and there is a return card. If he is taken on, then the card in which the particulars are properly entered will be sent back to the Employment Exchange by the employer. The registrant's name will then be removed from the register. In other words, he is already an employed person and his name does not remain in the register. The card that he originally had will serve no purpose whatsoever.

ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT
BOARD (TRANSFER OF ASSETS)
BILL
First Reading


2.57 p.m.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker. Sir, I have the President's recommendation for the introduction of the Economic Development Board (Transfer of Assets) Bill.

Column: 18



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled "An Act to transfer certain assets of the Economic Development Board to the Minister for Finance."

    Bill read the First time.
Second Reading


    Mr Speaker: Second Reading, what day?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Now, Sir.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, I lay upon the Table a Certificate of Urgency signed by the President in respect of the Economic Development Board (Transfer of Assets) Bill.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Certificate is in order. Are typed or printed copies of the Bill available for distribution to Members?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Yes, Sir.

    Typed copies of the Bill distributed to hon. Members.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Economic Development Board (E.D.B.) which was established in 1961 has done valuable work in promoting industrial growth, developing industrial estates, financing industrial enterprises and providing technical training and consultant service to manufacturing industries. The scale of operations of the E.D.B, has expanded greatly since 1961, and this has magnified the basic conflict of the various functions which the E.D.B, was originally called upon to perform. Investment promotion, industrial financing and development and management of the industrial estates are functions each incompatible with the other and are best performed by separate organisations. Accordingly, on 1st June, 1968, the Jurong Town Corporation was Set up under an Act

Column: 19

of Parliament and commenced operations. The Corporation has taken over the ownership of the industrial lands and development functions of the E.D.B.

    A further separation of the functions of the E.D.B. took place on 1st September, 1968, when the Development Bank of Singapore (the Bank, for short), a private limited company, commenced operations. The Bank has taken over the industrial financing functions of the E.D.B.

    Since the E.D.B, is not now concerned with industrial financing but is concentrating on its main function of industrial promotion, clauses 2 and 3 of the Bill provide respectively for the transfer back to the Government of loans and debentures made, and stocks and shares subscribed, by the E.D.B, in industrial enterprises. Clause 4 provides for moneys invested in securities or deposited by E.D.B, to be transferred back to the Government according to the directions of the Minister for Finance.

    The E.D.B, loan portfolio, when returned to the Government, will be assigned by the Government to the Bank. The equity investments and all other assets will be retained by the Government. The transfer to the Bank of the E.D.B, loan portfolio is made via the Government, so that the total value of this loan portfolio can be treated as a loan from the Government to the Bank on which a reasonable rate of interest will be charged.

    The transfer of the assets of the E.D.B, to the Government is made in the name of the Minister for Finance, who is a corporation sole, a legal entity established by law to hold investments of the Government.

    It will be noted from clause I of the Bill that the operation of the Bill is with retrospective effect as from 1st September. 1968, which is the date of commencement of operations of the Bank.

Column: 20



    With the establishment of the Jurong Town Corporation and the Development Bank of Singapore, the rationalisation of the structure of the E.D.B, is now complete. The E.D.B, will henceforth concentrate on its major functions of industrial promotion as well as of assistance in overcoming technical and managerial problems of individual firms. Funds to run the E.D.B, will be provided annually as a subvention from the Government.

    Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker. Sir, will the Parliamentary Secretary please give the reasons for the urgency to bulldoze the Bill through the House?
